The Chapter on the Precepts for Mantra Practice in the Ritual Procedures for Making Offerings in the MahÄvairocana SÅ«tra, Scroll 1. Explaining this sÅ«tra has four parts: First, stating the main points; Second, discussing the origins; Third, explaining the title; Fourth, explaining the text.

First, stating the main points: The ultimate principle of true nature is beyond words and images, manifesting in response to beings without revealing any characteristics. It is said to be the wondrous and bright principle of the gates such as the letter A.

Now, this sutra, whose principle is contained in the words, and whose meaning transcends the text, is therefore empowered by the spiritual power of the Tathagata, with secret seals corresponding to it, and guided by mantras. The reason is that if one does not learn and receive the precepts from a teacher, one is prohibited from entering its gate. For those who are not suitable recipients, it is prohibited to transmit it to them without authorization. Those who have not yet received abhiseka are prohibited from hearing it by chance.
If one obtains to see, hear, and bow to it, one will eliminate sins as numerous as the sands of the Ganges;
If one practices as instructed, the ocean of virtues will gather in one's body.
Next, as for explaining the origin, in the past, in the country of Central India, there were four sons of a king. When the king was about to die, the queen asked:
After the great king passes away, which son will succeed to the throne?
The king immediately replied:
The youngest son is capable of succeeding to the throne.
After the father king passed away, the great ministers and officials all gathered and asked about the last instructions. The queen immediately replied as the king had said before his death.
At that time, the queen, the younger brothers, and the ministers invited the youngest prince to succeed to the throne. The youngest prince replied:
I have a vow to renounce the world and study the path, hoping to save all beings.
I am not fit to succeed to the throne.
The queen and others repeatedly requested him as per the late king's will, but the youngest prince also declined as before.
After the queen and others made repeated requests, they forcefully ordered him to succeed to the throne. The youngest prince did not dare disobey, so he ascended the throne.
Later, he further contemplated:
If I stay in this country, I cannot renounce the world.
My aunt is the queen of a neighboring country. I should go to her for refuge. She will surely allow me to renounce the world.
He skillfully escaped and fled to her country.
When he reached the border of that country, a garrison commander asked him:
Who are you?
The youngest prince replied:
I am the king of the country of Central India.
The garrison commander said:
If you are the king, why did you come alone?
He replied:

I originally hoped to leave the household life and study the path. If I stayed in my homeland for a long time, I would definitely not be able to leave the household life. I deeply hope to leave the household life and study the path.
He bowed and sent a messenger to report.
The queen heard about it and sent someone to welcome him.
The youngest son saw the queen, knelt down, and spoke of his aspirations.
When the queen heard his words, she wept sorrowfully and compassionately. After a long while, she said:
Your surname is Kshatriya, the grandson of King Shuddhodana, and a distant nephew of Shakyamuni Buddha.
I have heard that Shakyamuni abandoned the position of crown prince, left the city to enter the path, and attained supreme enlightenment.

The most difficult thing to give up in the world is to abandon the precious position of king. You have abandoned the position of king like Shakyamuni, made a great vow, and will surely attain Buddhahood.
From today onwards, you will follow the people in holding a bowl to beg for food, and eat coarse rice while fasting.
You can feel sad about this.
Nevertheless, the great man's hope is to wholeheartedly vow, with no other choice.
He then agreed to let him go forth.
He requested a virtuous master from within the realm to become his disciple and study the teachings.

The younger one, with a clear and wise nature, understood the subtle principles upon hearing them once, and with two questions could comprehend a thousand or a hundred. Although he had not studied for many years, he had thoroughly mastered what he had learned.
Then the master said,
What I understand is exhausted, and there is nothing more to expound.
I have heard that in that country there are wise and virtuous sages, you should go there to study.
The younger one respectfully followed the instruction, took leave, and withdrew.
He went to the wise teacher's place and studied as before.
He traveled through more than fifty countries, reaching North India, where there was a city named Gandhara.

The king of that country relied on the preceptor to receive the Dharma and recite the sutra. The text was extensive and the meaning profound, so he was unable to search through it all. He made offerings and requested the preceptor for the method of making offerings.

The preceptor accepted the request and sought the holy one's blessings by the side of the stupa built by King Kanakavatsa. Suddenly, this method of making offerings appeared in the sky, with the golden characters shining brightly.
The preceptor read it once briefly and clearly remembered it. He looked up to the sky and said:
Who created this?
It said:
I created it.
He said:
Who are you?
It said:
I am Manjushri.
He then called a scribe to write it down. He gave a copy to the king and wrote a copy himself to distribute to the four directions as he traveled.

It is an inconceivable blessing to be able to consult the preceptor in person and record what I have heard of the essential teachings to the best of my ability.

The Indian language has sixteen dhÅ«tas, but the sÅ«tras and Å›Ästras only mention twelve.
The sixteen are divided into four categories of robes, six categories of food, and six categories of dwelling places.
The four categories of robes are:
Wearing rag robes, wearing robes made of felt, wearing patched robes, and keeping the three robes.
Rag robes are robes burned by fire, chewed by cows, gnawed by rats, or worn by dead people.
In foreign countries, such robes are discarded in the streets and fields, treated like garbage, and are thus called rags.
The practitioner takes them, washes, dyes, sews, and repairs them to use for covering the body.
Question:
Why only accept these robes?
There are three levels:

The lower level is to obtain robes through wrong livelihoods such as trading and various improper means;ğŸ”½The middle level is to avoid the above faults and accept robes from the saá¹ƒgha or robes given by laypeople;
The higher level is to neither accept from the saá¹ƒgha nor from laypeople, but to accept rags.
Why not accept the robe from the Sangha?
The Sangha's method requires uniformity in handling Sangha affairs, assigning tasks, and resolving disputes. Distraction disturbs the path.
Why not accept and go beyond?
If one accepts and goes beyond, in pursuit of robes, one often falls into wrong livelihood.
Moreover, it gives rise to attachment, making it difficult to escape.
Moreover, one becomes intimate with those who give and distant from those who do not, obstructing equal teaching.
Moreover, one often gives rise to arrogance and resentment towards those who do not give.
They lack knowledge and do not recognize who is a field of merit to whom alms should be given or not. They may feel ashamed and give rise to worry and regret.
Moreover, often going [to beg] disturbs the path, and not going leads to resentment.
Moreover, one hates good people and slanders the virtuous.
One does not wish to go.
Seeing these many faults, one does not accept robes given in advance.
Why only accept rags?
Few affairs increase the path, leaving faults and without offenses, so one only accepts them.
As for the word wool, it refers to the fine wool of wet-washed birds and beasts.
The practitioner has no rags to take, and obtains this as clothing.
As for the rag robe, it is made of old, worn-out, tattered rags sewn together to cover the body, not wearing fine clothes.
What is the reason?
If one seeks fine clothes, it gives rise to trouble and brings about offenses, wasting effort and neglecting the Way.
Moreover, when fine clothes are not obtained, the practitioner gives rise to a place of greedy attachment.
Moreover, in the wilderness, it often leads to the danger of thieves, or even to the loss of life.
As for the three robes, they are the five-strip robe, the seven-strip robe, and the large robe.
Those of superior practice only accept these three, not keeping any other clothes.
What is the reason?
Laypeople seek pleasure and keep various kinds of clothing.
Non-Buddhists who practice austerities go naked, without shame.
The Buddha abides in the middle way, abandoning the two extremes, and therefore keeps the three robes.
Moreover, seeking many robes wastes effort and neglects the Way. Few do not help matters. Keeping the three robes,
however, the three robes are sufficient for covering the body.
If working on projects, going to the bathroom, or coming and going, wear the five-strip robe.
For good deeds, wear the seven-part robe.
In order to transform and attract laypeople to reach reverence and faith, one should wear the large outer robe.
Also, when in a secluded place, wear the five-part robe, when entering the assembly, wear the seven-part robe, if entering the king's palace or village, one should wear the large outer robe.
Also, when the weather is mild, wear the five-part robe, when it is cold, add the seven-part robe, when the cold is severe, add the large outer robe.

Therefore, once in the right winter, the night was cold and cracked. The TathÄgata at that time, in the first part of the night, wore the five-part robe. As the night deepened and turned cold, he added the seven-part robe. In the latter part of the night, the cold of the sky turned severe, and he added the large outer robe.
The Buddha then thought:
In the future, for good men who cannot endure the suffering of cold, these three robes will be enough to cover the body.
For these many reasons, one keeps the three robes.

The six types of food: 1. begging for food, 2. begging for food in order, 3. not performing the remainder food method, 4. eating in one sitting, 5. eating in one portion also called moderation, 6. not drinking water after noon.
Begging for food, among humans there are three types:
inferior, middling, and superior.
The inferior class, although allowed to leave home, sustains themselves through wrong livelihood.
Farming, planting, and making a living through various crafts and wrong livelihoods.
The middling class abandons the previous faults and receives the food of the Saá¹…gha and also accepts invitations.
The superior practitioner does not receive the food of the Saá¹…gha or accept invitations, only practicing begging for food.
Why do they not receive the food of the Saá¹…gha or accept invitations?
The faults are the same as before.
For what meaning do they exclusively practice begging for food?
There are two reasons:
First, for oneself to reduce affairs and cultivate the Way, second, for the sake of others to bring blessings to the world.
Begging for food in order is also included in the category of begging for food.
It shows that when begging for food, one should avoid one-sided faults. Ordinary fools, discussing separately, crave flavors, abandon the poor and follow the rich;
Those of lesser practice have narrow compassion, abandon the rich and follow the poor;
Those of higher practice, the stream, leave craving, abandon narrowness, have equal compassion for sentient beings, and do not discriminate between rich and poor, begging in order.
As for not performing the remainder food ritual, the Vinaya says:
There are people who, although they beg for food in order, often obtain proper food at the places they seek, and eat frequently using the remainder food ritual.
The practitioner thinks:
Although the World-Honored One has allowed the sick to perform this remainder food ritual, I am not sick now and should not accept it. Therefore, I will not perform the remainder food ritual.
Since it is included in the single sitting meal, it is often not explained separately in the sÅ«tras and treatises.
The Vinaya explains it separately. That single sitting meal does not eat other small meals before noon.
This is about avoiding eating proper food frequently. Since there are differences, it is explained separately.
As for eating only one meal a day, some people may not eat frequently but may eat other pastries, cakes, porridge, etc. before noon.
The practitioner thinks:
Foolish people nourish their bodies, increasing afflictions and receiving them frequently.
I now practice the Way, not to nourish my body, to destroy afflictions, not to increase bonds, so I receive one meal.
He also thinks:
Seeking one meal already interferes with the Way, let alone seeking many meals.
Therefore, I only eat one meal.
He also observes that if he eats too much, it will give rise to many afflictions, so he receives one meal.
He also observes that the food is offered with faith, and one meal is hard to digest, let alone many meals.
Therefore, he receives one meal.
As for eating only one portion, the sÅ«tras also call it eating in moderation.
Receiving it once and stopping is called eating one portion.
Eating sparingly is called eating in moderation, let alone being lax.

There are people who, although they observe the precept of one meal a day, still eat to the point of fullness and sleepiness, wasting half a day and obstructing the practice of the Dharma. Therefore, one should eat in moderation.
Moreover, eating too much increases afflictions and makes them difficult to subdue, so one should eat in moderation.
Furthermore, eating too much increases sleepiness and makes it difficult to digest, causing the body to be uncomfortable, so one should eat in moderation.
Moreover, practitioners seek the Dharma body and gradually abandon the body of food, so they should eat in moderation.
To what extent should one eat in moderation?
According to one's ability, leave one-third for birds and beasts, and then eat the rest. It is good to eat less.

As for not drinking beverages after noon, there are people who, although they eat in moderation, still crave flavors and drink various beverages, fruit juices, honey drinks, molasses drinks, etc., after noon.
In pursuit of these drinks, they often engage in wrong livelihood, wasting their efforts and neglecting the path, so they do not drink.

Moreover, contemplating this mind is difficult to let loose and unrestrained, like a horse without reins eating grass to the left and right, unable to quickly follow the driver's intention, adding reins can make it advance quickly and go according to one's intention, therefore it is cut off.
There are six in the middle:

Why is this?
The practitioner thinks:
I originally lived at home, my parents and relatives entangled with each other, I abandoned them for this.
Now that I have left the household life, if I were to return to form bonds with teachers, fellow students, and acquaintances, it would be no different from being a layperson.
Therefore, I must abandon them and stay in the wilderness.
Moreover, in villages, men and women are mixed together, and it easily increases worldly attachments, so it is not suitable to stay there.

Furthermore, near villages, the sounds are chaotic and noisy, and it interferes with cultivating concentration.ğŸ”½As for between graves, between graves there are often corpses, rotting and stinking, and by observing the foul stench, it is easy to enter the contemplation of impurity.

Furthermore, between graves, the bones are scattered and separated, and by seeing this, it is easy to enter the contemplation of emptiness and no-self.
Therefore, one stays between graves.
As for under trees, previously, between graves, one observes corpses and accomplishes the path, so one abandons the graves and comes to stay under trees.

Moreover, previously at the charnel ground, one takes the appearance of the dead body, but there are many sounds of crying and so forth that interfere with the cultivation of calming and insight, so one comes to the foot of a tree to concentrate the mind and contemplate.
Moreover, the shade of a tree is the same as half a house, peacefully dwelling and cultivating the Way, so one is at the foot of a tree.
The Buddhas and sages who attain the Way and realize the fruits often rely on trees, so one is at the foot of a tree.
As for sitting in the open air, the shade under a tree is damp, and dwelling there for a long time leads to illness, so one goes to the open air.
Moreover, there are many birds in the trees, their sounds are noisy and distracting, interfering with the cultivation of concentration, so one is in the open air.

Moreover, the practitioner has been under a tree for a long time, and the mind becomes attached to the tree, or one further discriminates that this is good and that is bad, in order to eliminate this affliction, so one must abandon the tree and come to the open air.
It is clearly manifested, that is to say, unobstructed, so one is in the open air.
Moreover, the bright moonlight shines in the open air, and the mind is bright and pure, easily entering concentration, so one is in the open air.

As for constant sitting, among the four dignified deportments, walking and standing are too tiring, and lying down is too comfortable. Sitting avoids these two extremes and is capable of lasting a long time, so one must always sit.
Moreover, when walking or standing, the mind is agitated and difficult to control;
when lying down, one becomes drowsy and falls asleep.
Sitting avoids sinking and agitation, so one must always sit.

Moreover, one who seeks the Way has not yet accomplished the great matter. The thieves of afflictions always watch for an opportunity to take advantage. It is not suitable to lie down comfortably, so one must always sit.
Moreover, there are many accomplishments in the middle. Food is easily digested and breath is harmonized, so one must always sit.
As for following sitting, one sits wherever there is grass or ground, so it is called following sitting.
